trans-unit.source: Automatically scale compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Automatically scale compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Enable automatic scaling on a cloud pool to dynamically adjust the number of compute nodes in the pool.
trans-unit.target: Enable automatic scaling on a cloud pool to dynamically adjust the number of compute nodes in the pool.

trans-unit.source: Automatically scale compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool
trans-unit.target: Automatically scale compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool

trans-unit.source: By using automatic scaling in Azure Batch, you can dynamically add or remove compute nodes in a Batch pool during job execution to automatically adjust the processing power that is used by your application.
trans-unit.target: By using automatic scaling in Azure Batch, you can dynamically add or remove compute nodes in a Batch pool during job execution to automatically adjust the processing power that is used by your application.

trans-unit.source: This automatic adjustment can save you both time and money.
trans-unit.target: This automatic adjustment can save you both time and money.

trans-unit.source: You can enable automatic scaling on a pool of compute nodes by associating an *autoscale formula* with the pool, such as with the [PoolOperations.EnableAutoScale][net_enableautoscale] method in the [Batch .NET](batch-dotnet-get-started.md) library.
trans-unit.target: You can enable automatic scaling on a pool of compute nodes by associating an *autoscale formula* with the pool, such as with the [PoolOperations.EnableAutoScale][net_enableautoscale] method in the [Batch .NET](batch-dotnet-get-started.md) library.

trans-unit.source: The Batch service then uses this formula to determine the number of compute nodes that are needed to execute your workload.
trans-unit.target: The Batch service then uses this formula to determine the number of compute nodes that are needed to execute your workload.

trans-unit.source: The number of compute nodes in the pool, which responds to service metrics data samples that are collected periodically, is adjusted at a configurable interval based on the associated formula.
trans-unit.target: The number of compute nodes in the pool, which responds to service metrics data samples that are collected periodically, is adjusted at a configurable interval based on the associated formula.

trans-unit.source: You can enable automatic scaling when a pool is created, or on an existing pool.
trans-unit.target: You can enable automatic scaling when a pool is created, or on an existing pool.

trans-unit.source: You can also change an existing formula on a pool that is "autoscale" enabled.
trans-unit.target: You can also change an existing formula on a pool that is "autoscale" enabled.

trans-unit.source: Batch provides the ability to evaluate your formulas before assigning them to pools, as well as for monitoring the status of automatic scaling runs.
trans-unit.target: Batch provides the ability to evaluate your formulas before assigning them to pools, as well as for monitoring the status of automatic scaling runs.

trans-unit.source: Automatic scaling formulas
trans-unit.target: Automatic scaling formulas

trans-unit.source: An automatic scaling formula is a string value that contains one or more statements that are assigned to a pool's [autoScaleFormula][rest_autoscaleformula] element (Batch REST API), or the [CloudPool.AutoScaleFormula][net_cloudpool_autoscaleformula] property (Batch .NET API).
trans-unit.target: An automatic scaling formula is a string value that contains one or more statements that are assigned to a pool's [autoScaleFormula][rest_autoscaleformula] element (Batch REST API), or the [CloudPool.AutoScaleFormula][net_cloudpool_autoscaleformula] property (Batch .NET API).

trans-unit.source: You define these formulas.
trans-unit.target: You define these formulas.

trans-unit.source: When they are assigned to a pool, they determine the number of available compute nodes in a pool for the next interval of processing (see more on intervals later).
trans-unit.target: When they are assigned to a pool, they determine the number of available compute nodes in a pool for the next interval of processing (see more on intervals later).

trans-unit.source: The formula string cannot exceed 8 KB in size, can include up to 100 statements that are separated by semicolons, and can include line breaks and comments.
trans-unit.target: The formula string cannot exceed 8 KB in size, can include up to 100 statements that are separated by semicolons, and can include line breaks and comments.

trans-unit.source: You can think of automatic scaling formulas as using a Batch autoscale "language."
trans-unit.target: You can think of automatic scaling formulas as using a Batch autoscale "language."

trans-unit.source: Formula statements are free-formed expressions that can include system-defined and user-defined variables, as well as constants.
trans-unit.target: Formula statements are free-formed expressions that can include system-defined and user-defined variables, as well as constants.

trans-unit.source: They can perform various operations on these values by using built-in types, operators, and functions.
trans-unit.target: They can perform various operations on these values by using built-in types, operators, and functions.

trans-unit.source: For example, a statement might take the following form:
trans-unit.target: For example, a statement might take the following form:

trans-unit.source: Formulas generally contain multiple statements that perform operations on values that are obtained in previous statements:
trans-unit.target: Formulas generally contain multiple statements that perform operations on values that are obtained in previous statements:

trans-unit.source: By using the statements in your formula, your goal is to arrive at a number of compute nodes that the pool should be scaled to--the **target** number of **dedicated nodes**.
trans-unit.target: By using the statements in your formula, your goal is to arrive at a number of compute nodes that the pool should be scaled to--the **target** number of **dedicated nodes**.

trans-unit.source: This number may be higher, lower, or the same as the current number of nodes in the pool.
trans-unit.target: This number may be higher, lower, or the same as the current number of nodes in the pool.

trans-unit.source: Batch evaluates a pool's autoscale formula at a specific interval ([automatic scaling intervals](#interval) are discussed below).
trans-unit.target: Batch evaluates a pool's autoscale formula at a specific interval ([automatic scaling intervals](#interval) are discussed below).

trans-unit.source: Then it will adjust the target number of nodes in the pool to the number that your autoscale formula specifies at the time of evaluation.
trans-unit.target: Then it will adjust the target number of nodes in the pool to the number that your autoscale formula specifies at the time of evaluation.

trans-unit.source: As a quick example, this two-line autoscale formula specifies that the number of nodes should be adjusted according to the number of active tasks, up to a maximum of 10 compute nodes:
trans-unit.target: As a quick example, this two-line autoscale formula specifies that the number of nodes should be adjusted according to the number of active tasks, up to a maximum of 10 compute nodes:

trans-unit.source: The next few sections of this article discuss the various entities that will make up your autoscale formulas, including variables, operators, operations, and functions.
trans-unit.target: The next few sections of this article discuss the various entities that will make up your autoscale formulas, including variables, operators, operations, and functions.

trans-unit.source: You'll find out how to obtain various compute resource and task metrics within Batch.
trans-unit.target: You'll find out how to obtain various compute resource and task metrics within Batch.

trans-unit.source: You can use these metrics to intelligently adjust your pool's node count based on resource usage and task status.
trans-unit.target: You can use these metrics to intelligently adjust your pool's node count based on resource usage and task status.

trans-unit.source: You'll then learn how to construct a formula and enable automatic scaling on a pool by using both the Batch REST and .NET APIs.
trans-unit.target: You'll then learn how to construct a formula and enable automatic scaling on a pool by using both the Batch REST and .NET APIs.

trans-unit.source: We'll finish up with a few example formulas.
trans-unit.target: We'll finish up with a few example formulas.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Each Azure Batch account is limited to a maximum number of compute nodes that can be used for processing.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Each Azure Batch account is limited to a maximum number of compute nodes that can be used for processing.

trans-unit.source: The Batch service will create nodes only up to that limit.
trans-unit.target: The Batch service will create nodes only up to that limit.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it may not reach the target number that is specified by a formula.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it may not reach the target number that is specified by a formula.

trans-unit.source: See [Quotas and limits for the Azure Batch service](batch-quota-limit.md) for information on viewing and increasing your account quotas.
trans-unit.target: See [Quotas and limits for the Azure Batch service](batch-quota-limit.md) for information on viewing and increasing your account quotas.

trans-unit.source: Variables
trans-unit.target: Variables

trans-unit.source: You can use both system-defined and user-defined variables in autoscale formulas.
trans-unit.target: You can use both system-defined and user-defined variables in autoscale formulas.

trans-unit.source: In the two-line example formula above, `$TargetDedicated` is a system-defined variable, while `$averageActiveTaskCount` is user-defined.
trans-unit.target: In the two-line example formula above, `$TargetDedicated` is a system-defined variable, while `$averageActiveTaskCount` is user-defined.

trans-unit.source: The tables below show both read-write and read-only variables that are defined by the Batch service.
trans-unit.target: The tables below show both read-write and read-only variables that are defined by the Batch service.

trans-unit.target: *Get* and *set* the values of these **system-defined variables** to manage the number of compute nodes in a pool:

trans-unit.source: Variables (read-write)
trans-unit.target: Variables (read-write)

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: $TargetDedicated
trans-unit.target: $TargetDedicated

trans-unit.source: The target number of dedicated compute nodes for the pool.
trans-unit.target: The target number of dedicated compute nodes for the pool.

trans-unit.source: This is the number of compute nodes that the pool should be scaled to.
trans-unit.target: This is the number of compute nodes that the pool should be scaled to.

trans-unit.source: It is a "target" number since it's possible for a pool not to reach the target number of nodes.
trans-unit.target: It is a "target" number since it's possible for a pool not to reach the target number of nodes.

trans-unit.source: This can occur if the target number of nodes is modified again by a subsequent autoscale evaluation before the pool has reached the initial target.
trans-unit.target: This can occur if the target number of nodes is modified again by a subsequent autoscale evaluation before the pool has reached the initial target.

trans-unit.source: It can also happen if a Batch account node or core quota is reached before the target number of nodes is reached.
trans-unit.target: It can also happen if a Batch account node or core quota is reached before the target number of nodes is reached.

trans-unit.source: $NodeDeallocationOption
trans-unit.target: $NodeDeallocationOption

trans-unit.source: The action that occurs when compute nodes are removed from a pool.
trans-unit.target: The action that occurs when compute nodes are removed from a pool.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are:
trans-unit.target: Possible values are:

trans-unit.source: requeue--Terminates tasks immediately and puts them back on the job queue so that they are rescheduled.
trans-unit.target: requeue--Terminates tasks immediately and puts them back on the job queue so that they are rescheduled.

trans-unit.source: terminate--Terminates tasks immediately and removes them from the job queue.
trans-unit.target: terminate--Terminates tasks immediately and removes them from the job queue.

trans-unit.source: taskcompletion--Waits for currently running tasks to finish and then removes the node from the pool.
trans-unit.target: taskcompletion--Waits for currently running tasks to finish and then removes the node from the pool.

trans-unit.source: retaineddata--Waits for all the local task-retained data on the node to be cleaned up before removing the node from the pool.
trans-unit.target: retaineddata--Waits for all the local task-retained data on the node to be cleaned up before removing the node from the pool.

trans-unit.source: The GetSample() method returns a vector of data samples.

trans-unit.source: A sample is 30 seconds worth of metrics data.
trans-unit.target: A sample is 30 seconds worth of metrics data.

trans-unit.source: In other words, samples are obtained every 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: In other words, samples are obtained every 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: But as noted below, there is a delay between when a sample is collected and when it is available to a formula.
trans-unit.target: But as noted below, there is a delay between when a sample is collected and when it is available to a formula.

trans-unit.source: As such, not all samples for a given time period may be available for evaluation by a formula.
trans-unit.target: As such, not all samples for a given time period may be available for evaluation by a formula.

trans-unit.source: doubleVec GetSample(double count)--Specifies the number of samples to obtain from the most recent samples that were collected.
trans-unit.target: doubleVec GetSample(double count)--Specifies the number of samples to obtain from the most recent samples that were collected.

trans-unit.source: GetSample(1) returns the last available sample.
trans-unit.target: GetSample(1) returns the last available sample.

trans-unit.source: For metrics like $CPUPercent, however, this should not be used because it is impossible to know when the sample was collected.
trans-unit.target: For metrics like $CPUPercent, however, this should not be used because it is impossible to know when the sample was collected.

trans-unit.source: It might be recent, or, because of system issues, it might be much older.
trans-unit.target: It might be recent, or, because of system issues, it might be much older.

trans-unit.source: It is better in such cases to use a time interval as shown below.
trans-unit.target: It is better in such cases to use a time interval as shown below.

trans-unit.source: doubleVec GetSample((timestamp | timeinterval) startTime [, double samplePercent])--Specifies a time frame for gathering sample data.
trans-unit.target: doubleVec GetSample((timestamp | timeinterval) startTime [, double samplePercent])--Specifies a time frame for gathering sample data.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, it also specifies the percentage of samples that must be available in the requested time frame.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, it also specifies the percentage of samples that must be available in the requested time frame.

trans-unit.source: $CPUPercent.GetSample(TimeInterval_Minute * 10) would return 20 samples if all samples for the last ten minutes are present in the CPUPercent history.
trans-unit.target: $CPUPercent.GetSample(TimeInterval_Minute * 10) would return 20 samples if all samples for the last ten minutes are present in the CPUPercent history.

trans-unit.source: If the last minute of history was not available, however, only 18 samples would be returned.
trans-unit.target: If the last minute of history was not available, however, only 18 samples would be returned.

trans-unit.source: In this case:
trans-unit.target: In this case:

trans-unit.source: $CPUPercent.GetSample(TimeInterval_Minute * 10, 95) would fail because only 90 percent of the samples are available.
trans-unit.target: $CPUPercent.GetSample(TimeInterval_Minute * 10, 95) would fail because only 90 percent of the samples are available.

trans-unit.source: $CPUPercent.GetSample(TimeInterval_Minute * 10, 80) would succeed.
trans-unit.target: $CPUPercent.GetSample(TimeInterval_Minute * 10, 80) would succeed.

trans-unit.source: doubleVec GetSample((timestamp | timeinterval) startTime, (timestamp | timeinterval) endTime [, double samplePercent])--Specifies a time frame for gathering data, with both a start time and an end time.
trans-unit.target: doubleVec GetSample((timestamp | timeinterval) startTime, (timestamp | timeinterval) endTime [, double samplePercent])--Specifies a time frame for gathering data, with both a start time and an end time.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned above, there is a delay between when a sample is collected and when it is available to a formula.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned above, there is a delay between when a sample is collected and when it is available to a formula.

trans-unit.source: This must be considered when you use the GetSample method.
trans-unit.target: This must be considered when you use the GetSample method.

trans-unit.source: See GetSamplePercent below.
trans-unit.target: See GetSamplePercent below.

trans-unit.target: GetSamplePercent()

trans-unit.source: Returns the percentage of samples that are available for a given time interval.
trans-unit.target: Returns the percentage of samples that are available for a given time interval.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.target: doubleVec GetSamplePercent( (timestamp | timeinterval) startTime [, (timestamp | timeinterval) endTime] )

trans-unit.source: Because the GetSample method fails if the percentage of samples returned is less than the samplePercent specified, you can use the GetSamplePercent method to check first.
trans-unit.target: Because the GetSample method fails if the percentage of samples returned is less than the samplePercent specified, you can use the GetSamplePercent method to check first.

trans-unit.source: Samples, sample percentage, and the *GetSample()* method
trans-unit.target: Samples, sample percentage, and the *GetSample()* method

trans-unit.source: The core operation of an autoscale formula is to obtain task and resource metric data and then adjust pool size based on that data.
trans-unit.target: The core operation of an autoscale formula is to obtain task and resource metric data and then adjust pool size based on that data.

trans-unit.source: As such, it is important to have a clear understanding of how autoscale formulas interact with metrics data, or "samples."
trans-unit.target: As such, it is important to have a clear understanding of how autoscale formulas interact with metrics data, or "samples."

trans-unit.source: Samples
trans-unit.target: Samples

trans-unit.source: The Batch service periodically takes *samples* of task and resource metrics and makes them available to your autoscale formulas.
trans-unit.target: The Batch service periodically takes *samples* of task and resource metrics and makes them available to your autoscale formulas.

trans-unit.source: These samples are recorded every 30 seconds by the Batch service.
trans-unit.target: These samples are recorded every 30 seconds by the Batch service.

trans-unit.source: However, there is typically some latency that causes a delay between when those samples were recorded and when they are made available to (and can be read by) your autoscale formulas.
trans-unit.target: However, there is typically some latency that causes a delay between when those samples were recorded and when they are made available to (and can be read by) your autoscale formulas.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, due to various factors such as network or other infrastructure issues, samples may not have been recorded for a particular interval.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, due to various factors such as network or other infrastructure issues, samples may not have been recorded for a particular interval.

trans-unit.source: This results in "missing" samples.
trans-unit.target: This results in "missing" samples.

trans-unit.source: Sample percentage
trans-unit.target: Sample percentage

trans-unit.source: When `samplePercent` is passed to the `GetSample()` method or the `GetSamplePercent()` method is called, "percent" refers to a comparison between the total *possible* number of samples that are recorded by the Batch service and the number of samples that are actually *available* to your autoscale formula.
trans-unit.target: When `samplePercent` is passed to the `GetSample()` method or the `GetSamplePercent()` method is called, "percent" refers to a comparison between the total *possible* number of samples that are recorded by the Batch service and the number of samples that are actually *available* to your autoscale formula.

trans-unit.source: Let's look at a 10-minute timespan as an example.
trans-unit.target: Let's look at a 10-minute timespan as an example.

trans-unit.source: Because samples are recorded every 30 seconds, within a 10 minute timespan, the maximum total number of samples that are recorded by Batch would be 20 samples (2 per minute).
trans-unit.target: Because samples are recorded every 30 seconds, within a 10 minute timespan, the maximum total number of samples that are recorded by Batch would be 20 samples (2 per minute).

trans-unit.source: However, due to the inherent latency of the reporting mechanism or some other issue within the Azure infrastructure, there may be only 15 samples that are available to your autoscale formula for reading.
trans-unit.target: However, due to the inherent latency of the reporting mechanism or some other issue within the Azure infrastructure, there may be only 15 samples that are available to your autoscale formula for reading.

trans-unit.source: This means that, for that 10-minute period, only **75 percent** of the total number of samples recorded are actually available to your formula.
trans-unit.target: This means that, for that 10-minute period, only **75 percent** of the total number of samples recorded are actually available to your formula.

trans-unit.source: GetSample() and sample ranges
trans-unit.target: GetSample() and sample ranges

trans-unit.source: Your autoscale formulas are going to be growing and shrinking your pools--adding nodes or removing nodes.
trans-unit.target: Your autoscale formulas are going to be growing and shrinking your pools--adding nodes or removing nodes.

trans-unit.source: Because nodes cost you money, you want to ensure that your formulas use an intelligent method of analysis that is based on sufficient data.
trans-unit.target: Because nodes cost you money, you want to ensure that your formulas use an intelligent method of analysis that is based on sufficient data.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, we recommend that you use a trending-type analysis in your formulas.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, we recommend that you use a trending-type analysis in your formulas.

trans-unit.source: This type will grow and shrink your pools based on a *range* of collected samples.
trans-unit.target: This type will grow and shrink your pools based on a *range* of collected samples.

trans-unit.source: To do so, use `GetSample(interval look-back start, interval look-back end)` to return a **vector** of samples:
trans-unit.target: To do so, use `GetSample(interval look-back start, interval look-back end)` to return a **vector** of samples:

trans-unit.source: When the above line is evaluated by Batch, it will return a range of samples as a vector of values.
trans-unit.target: When the above line is evaluated by Batch, it will return a range of samples as a vector of values.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Once you've collected the vector of samples, you can then use functions like `min()`, `max()`, and `avg()` to derive meaningful values from the collected range.
trans-unit.target: Once you've collected the vector of samples, you can then use functions like `min()`, `max()`, and `avg()` to derive meaningful values from the collected range.

trans-unit.source: For additional security, you can force a formula evaluation to *fail* if less than a certain sample percentage is available for a particular time period.
trans-unit.target: For additional security, you can force a formula evaluation to *fail* if less than a certain sample percentage is available for a particular time period.

trans-unit.source: When you force a formula evaluation to fail, you instruct Batch to cease further evaluation of the formula if the specified percentage of samples is not available--and no change to pool size will be made.
trans-unit.target: When you force a formula evaluation to fail, you instruct Batch to cease further evaluation of the formula if the specified percentage of samples is not available--and no change to pool size will be made.

trans-unit.source: To specify a required percentage of samples for the evaluation to succeed, specify it as the third parameter to `GetSample()`.
trans-unit.target: To specify a required percentage of samples for the evaluation to succeed, specify it as the third parameter to `GetSample()`.

trans-unit.source: Here, a requirement of 75 percent of samples is specified:
trans-unit.target: Here, a requirement of 75 percent of samples is specified:

trans-unit.source: It is also important, due to the previously mentioned delay in sample availability, to always specify a time range with a look-back start time that is older than one minute.
trans-unit.target: It is also important, due to the previously mentioned delay in sample availability, to always specify a time range with a look-back start time that is older than one minute.

trans-unit.source: This is because it takes approximately one minute for samples to propagate through the system, so samples in the range `(0 * TimeInterval_Second, 60 * TimeInterval_Second)` will often not be available.
trans-unit.target: This is because it takes approximately one minute for samples to propagate through the system, so samples in the range `(0 * TimeInterval_Second, 60 * TimeInterval_Second)` will often not be available.

trans-unit.source: Again, you can use the percentage parameter of `GetSample()` to force a particular sample percentage requirement.
trans-unit.target: Again, you can use the percentage parameter of `GetSample()` to force a particular sample percentage requirement.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] We **strongly recommend** that you **avoid relying *only* on `GetSample(1)` in your autoscale formulas**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] We **strongly recommend** that you **avoid relying *only* on `GetSample(1)` in your autoscale formulas**.

trans-unit.source: This is because `GetSample(1)` essentially says to the Batch service, "Give me the last sample you have, no matter how long ago you got it."
trans-unit.target: This is because `GetSample(1)` essentially says to the Batch service, "Give me the last sample you have, no matter how long ago you got it."

trans-unit.source: Since it is only a single sample, and it may be an older sample, it may not be representative of the larger picture of recent task or resource state.
trans-unit.target: Since it is only a single sample, and it may be an older sample, it may not be representative of the larger picture of recent task or resource state.

trans-unit.source: If you do use `GetSample(1)`, make sure that it's part of a larger statement and not the only data point that your formula relies on.
trans-unit.target: If you do use `GetSample(1)`, make sure that it's part of a larger statement and not the only data point that your formula relies on.

trans-unit.source: Metrics
trans-unit.target: Metrics

trans-unit.source: You can use both **resource** and **task** metrics when you're defining a formula.
trans-unit.target: You can use both **resource** and **task** metrics when you're defining a formula.

trans-unit.source: You adjust the target number of dedicated nodes in the pool based on the metrics data that you obtain and evaluate.
trans-unit.target: You adjust the target number of dedicated nodes in the pool based on the metrics data that you obtain and evaluate.

trans-unit.source: See the [Variables](#variables) section above for more information on each metric.
trans-unit.target: See the [Variables](#variables) section above for more information on each metric.

trans-unit.target: Resource metrics are based on the CPU, bandwidth, and memory usage of compute nodes, as well as the number of nodes.

trans-unit.source: Create a pool with automatic scaling enabled
trans-unit.target: Create a pool with automatic scaling enabled

trans-unit.source: To enable automatic scaling when you're creating a pool, use one of the following techniques:
trans-unit.target: To enable automatic scaling when you're creating a pool, use one of the following techniques:

trans-unit.source: [New-AzureBatchPool](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt125936.aspx)--This Azure PowerShell cmdlet uses the AutoScaleFormula parameter to specify the automatic scaling formula.
trans-unit.target: [New-AzureBatchPool](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt125936.aspx)--This Azure PowerShell cmdlet uses the AutoScaleFormula parameter to specify the automatic scaling formula.

trans-unit.source: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.CreatePool](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.createpool.aspx)--After this .NET method is called to create a pool, you'll then set the pool's [CloudPool.AutoScaleEnabled](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.cloudpool.autoscaleenabled.aspx) property and [CloudPool.AutoScaleFormula](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.cloudpool.autoscaleformula.aspx) property to enable automatic scaling.
trans-unit.target: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.CreatePool](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.createpool.aspx)--After this .NET method is called to create a pool, you'll then set the pool's [CloudPool.AutoScaleEnabled](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.cloudpool.autoscaleenabled.aspx) property and [CloudPool.AutoScaleFormula](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.cloudpool.autoscaleformula.aspx) property to enable automatic scaling.

trans-unit.source: [Add a pool to an account](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn820174.aspx)--The enableAutoScale and autoScaleFormula elements are used in this REST API request to set up automatic scaling for the pool when it is created.
trans-unit.target: [Add a pool to an account](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn820174.aspx)--The enableAutoScale and autoScaleFormula elements are used in this REST API request to set up automatic scaling for the pool when it is created.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] If you create an autoscale-enabled pool by using one of the above techniques, the *targetDedicated* parameter for the pool must **not** be specified.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] If you create an autoscale-enabled pool by using one of the above techniques, the *targetDedicated* parameter for the pool must **not** be specified.

trans-unit.source: Also note that if you wish to manually resize an autoscale-enabled pool (for example, with [BatchClient.PoolOperations.ResizePool][net_poolops_resizepool]), then you must first **disable** automatic scaling on the pool, then resize it.
trans-unit.target: Also note that if you wish to manually resize an autoscale-enabled pool (for example, with [BatchClient.PoolOperations.ResizePool][net_poolops_resizepool]), then you must first **disable** automatic scaling on the pool, then resize it.

trans-unit.target: The pool's autoscale formula sets the target number of nodes to five on Mondays, and one on every other day of the week.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the automatic scaling interval is set to 30 minutes (see [Automatic scaling interval](#interval) below).
trans-unit.target: In addition, the automatic scaling interval is set to 30 minutes (see [Automatic scaling interval](#interval) below).

trans-unit.source: Automatic scaling interval
trans-unit.target: Automatic scaling interval

trans-unit.source: By default, the Batch service adjusts a pool's size according to its autoscale formula every **15 minutes**.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Batch service adjusts a pool's size according to its autoscale formula every **15 minutes**.

trans-unit.source: This interval is configurable, however, by using the following pool properties:
trans-unit.target: This interval is configurable, however, by using the following pool properties:

trans-unit.source: REST API--[autoScaleEvaluationInterval][rest_autoscaleinterval]
trans-unit.target: REST API--[autoScaleEvaluationInterval][rest_autoscaleinterval]

trans-unit.source: .NET API--[CloudPool.AutoScaleEvaluationInterval][net_cloudpool_autoscaleevalinterval]
trans-unit.target: .NET API--[CloudPool.AutoScaleEvaluationInterval][net_cloudpool_autoscaleevalinterval]

trans-unit.source: The minimum interval is five minutes, and the maximum is 168 hours.
trans-unit.target: The minimum interval is five minutes, and the maximum is 168 hours.

trans-unit.source: If an interval outside this range is specified, the Batch service will return a Bad Request (400) error.
trans-unit.target: If an interval outside this range is specified, the Batch service will return a Bad Request (400) error.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Autoscaling is not currently intended to respond to changes in less than a minute, but rather is intended to adjust the size of your pool gradually as you run a workload.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Autoscaling is not currently intended to respond to changes in less than a minute, but rather is intended to adjust the size of your pool gradually as you run a workload.

trans-unit.source: Enable automatic scaling after a pool is created
trans-unit.target: Enable automatic scaling after a pool is created

trans-unit.source: If you've already set up a pool with a specified number of compute nodes by using the *targetDedicated* parameter, you can update the existing pool at a later time to automatically scale.
trans-unit.target: If you've already set up a pool with a specified number of compute nodes by using the *targetDedicated* parameter, you can update the existing pool at a later time to automatically scale.

trans-unit.source: You can do this in one of these ways:
trans-unit.target: You can do this in one of these ways:

trans-unit.source: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.EnableAutoScale][net_enableautoscale]--This .NET method requires the ID of an existing pool and the automatic scaling formula to apply to the pool.
trans-unit.target: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.EnableAutoScale][net_enableautoscale]--This .NET method requires the ID of an existing pool and the automatic scaling formula to apply to the pool.

trans-unit.source: [Enable automatic scaling on a pool][rest_enableautoscale]--This REST API request requires the ID of the existing pool in the URI and the automatic scaling formula in the request body.
trans-unit.target: [Enable automatic scaling on a pool][rest_enableautoscale]--This REST API request requires the ID of the existing pool in the URI and the automatic scaling formula in the request body.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If a value was specified for the *targetDedicated* parameter when the pool was created, it is ignored when the automatic scaling formula is evaluated.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If a value was specified for the *targetDedicated* parameter when the pool was created, it is ignored when the automatic scaling formula is evaluated.

trans-unit.source: Evaluate the automatic scaling formula
trans-unit.target: Evaluate the automatic scaling formula

trans-unit.source: Its always a good practice to evaluate a formula before you use it in your application.
trans-unit.target: Its always a good practice to evaluate a formula before you use it in your application.

trans-unit.source: A formula is evaluated by performing a "test run" of the formula on an existing pool.
trans-unit.target: A formula is evaluated by performing a "test run" of the formula on an existing pool.

trans-unit.source: Do this by using:
trans-unit.target: Do this by using:

trans-unit.source: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.EvaluateAutoScale](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.evaluateautoscale.aspx) or [BatchClient.PoolOperations.EvaluateAutoScaleAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.evaluateautoscaleasync.aspx)--These .NET methods require the ID of an existing pool and the string that contains the automatic scaling formula.
trans-unit.target: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.EvaluateAutoScale](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.evaluateautoscale.aspx) or [BatchClient.PoolOperations.EvaluateAutoScaleAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.evaluateautoscaleasync.aspx)--These .NET methods require the ID of an existing pool and the string that contains the automatic scaling formula.

trans-unit.source: The results of the call are contained in an instance of the [AutoScaleEvaluation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.autoscaleevaluation.aspx) class.
trans-unit.target: The results of the call are contained in an instance of the [AutoScaleEvaluation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.autoscaleevaluation.aspx) class.

trans-unit.source: [Evaluate an automatic scaling formula](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn820183.aspx)--In this REST API request, the pool ID is specified in the URI.
trans-unit.target: [Evaluate an automatic scaling formula](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn820183.aspx)--In this REST API request, the pool ID is specified in the URI.

trans-unit.source: The automatic scaling formula is specified in the *autoScaleFormula* element of the request body.
trans-unit.target: The automatic scaling formula is specified in the *autoScaleFormula* element of the request body.

trans-unit.source: The response of the operation contains any error information that might be related to the formula.
trans-unit.target: The response of the operation contains any error information that might be related to the formula.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To evaluate an autoscale formula, you must first have enabled autoscaling on the pool by using a valid formula.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To evaluate an autoscale formula, you must first have enabled autoscaling on the pool by using a valid formula.

trans-unit.source: Example formulas
trans-unit.target: Example formulas

trans-unit.source: Let's take a look at some examples that show just a few ways that formulas can be used to automatically scale compute resources in a pool.
trans-unit.target: Let's take a look at some examples that show just a few ways that formulas can be used to automatically scale compute resources in a pool.

trans-unit.source: Example 1: Time-based adjustment
trans-unit.target: Example 1: Time-based adjustment

trans-unit.source: Perhaps you want to adjust the pool size based on the day of the week and time of day, to increase or decrease the number of nodes in the pool accordingly:
trans-unit.target: Perhaps you want to adjust the pool size based on the day of the week and time of day, to increase or decrease the number of nodes in the pool accordingly:

trans-unit.source: This formula first obtains the current time.
trans-unit.target: This formula first obtains the current time.

trans-unit.source: If it's a weekday (1-5) and within working hours (8 AM to 6 PM), the target pool size is set to 20 nodes.
trans-unit.target: If it's a weekday (1-5) and within working hours (8 AM to 6 PM), the target pool size is set to 20 nodes.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the pool size is targeted at 10 nodes.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the pool size is targeted at 10 nodes.

trans-unit.source: Example 2: Task-based adjustment
trans-unit.target: Example 2: Task-based adjustment

trans-unit.source: In this example, the pool size is adjusted based on the number of tasks in the queue.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the pool size is adjusted based on the number of tasks in the queue.

trans-unit.source: Note that both comments and line breaks are acceptable in formula strings.
trans-unit.target: Note that both comments and line breaks are acceptable in formula strings.

trans-unit.source: Example 3: Accounting for parallel tasks
trans-unit.target: Example 3: Accounting for parallel tasks

trans-unit.source: This is another example that adjusts the pool size based on the number of tasks.
trans-unit.target: This is another example that adjusts the pool size based on the number of tasks.

trans-unit.source: This formula also takes into account the [MaxTasksPerComputeNode][net_maxtasks] value that has been set for the pool.
trans-unit.target: This formula also takes into account the [MaxTasksPerComputeNode][net_maxtasks] value that has been set for the pool.

trans-unit.source: This is particularly useful in situations where [parallel task execution](batch-parallel-node-tasks.md) has been enabled on your pool.
trans-unit.target: This is particularly useful in situations where [parallel task execution](batch-parallel-node-tasks.md) has been enabled on your pool.

trans-unit.source: Example 4: Setting an initial pool size
trans-unit.target: Example 4: Setting an initial pool size

trans-unit.source: This example shows a C# code snippet with an autoscale formula that sets the pool size to a certain number of nodes for an initial time period.
trans-unit.target: This example shows a C# code snippet with an autoscale formula that sets the pool size to a certain number of nodes for an initial time period.

trans-unit.source: Then it adjusts the pool size based on the number of running and active tasks after the initial time period has elapsed.
trans-unit.target: Then it adjusts the pool size based on the number of running and active tasks after the initial time period has elapsed.

trans-unit.source: The formula in the above code snippet:
trans-unit.target: The formula in the above code snippet:

trans-unit.source: Sets the initial pool size to four nodes.
trans-unit.target: Sets the initial pool size to four nodes.

trans-unit.source: Does not adjust the pool size within the first 10 minutes of the pool's lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: Does not adjust the pool size within the first 10 minutes of the pool's lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: After 10 minutes, obtains the max value of the number of running and active tasks within the past 60 minutes.
trans-unit.target: After 10 minutes, obtains the max value of the number of running and active tasks within the past 60 minutes.

trans-unit.source: If both values are 0 (indicating that no tasks were running or active in the last 60 minutes), the pool size is set to 0.
trans-unit.target: If both values are 0 (indicating that no tasks were running or active in the last 60 minutes), the pool size is set to 0.

trans-unit.source: If either value is greater than zero, no change is made.
trans-unit.target: If either value is greater than zero, no change is made.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: To fully assess the efficiency of your application, you might need to access a compute node.
trans-unit.target: To fully assess the efficiency of your application, you might need to access a compute node.

trans-unit.source: To take advantage of remote access, a user account must be added to the node that you want to access, and a Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) file must be retrieved for that node.
trans-unit.target: To take advantage of remote access, a user account must be added to the node that you want to access, and a Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) file must be retrieved for that node.

trans-unit.source: Add the user account in one of these ways:
trans-unit.target: Add the user account in one of these ways:

trans-unit.source: [New-AzureBatchVMUser](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt149846.aspx)--This PowerShell cmdlet takes the pool name, compute node name, account name, and password as parameters.
trans-unit.target: [New-AzureBatchVMUser](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt149846.aspx)--This PowerShell cmdlet takes the pool name, compute node name, account name, and password as parameters.

trans-unit.source: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.CreateComputeNodeUser](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.createcomputenodeuser.aspx)--This .NET method creates an instance of the [ComputeNodeUser](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.batch.computenodeuser.aspx) class, on which the account name and password can be set for the compute node.
trans-unit.target: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.CreateComputeNodeUser](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.createcomputenodeuser.aspx)--This .NET method creates an instance of the [ComputeNodeUser](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.batch.computenodeuser.aspx) class, on which the account name and password can be set for the compute node.

trans-unit.source: [ComputeNodeUser.Commit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.batch.computenodeuser.commit.aspx) is then called on the instance to create the user on that node.
trans-unit.target: [ComputeNodeUser.Commit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.batch.computenodeuser.commit.aspx) is then called on the instance to create the user on that node.

trans-unit.source: [Add a user account to a node](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn820137.aspx)--The name of the pool and the compute node are specified in the URI.
trans-unit.target: [Add a user account to a node](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn820137.aspx)--The name of the pool and the compute node are specified in the URI.

trans-unit.source: The account name and password are sent to the node in the request body of this REST API request.
trans-unit.target: The account name and password are sent to the node in the request body of this REST API request.

trans-unit.source: Get the RDP file:
trans-unit.target: Get the RDP file:

trans-unit.source: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.GetRDPFile](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.getrdpfile.aspx)--This .NET method requires the ID of the pool, the node ID, and the name of the RDP file to create.
trans-unit.target: [BatchClient.PoolOperations.GetRDPFile](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.batch.pooloperations.getrdpfile.aspx)--This .NET method requires the ID of the pool, the node ID, and the name of the RDP file to create.

trans-unit.source: [Get a remote desktop protocol file from a node](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn820120.aspx)--This REST API request requires the name of the pool and the name of the compute node.
trans-unit.target: [Get a remote desktop protocol file from a node](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn820120.aspx)--This REST API request requires the name of the pool and the name of the compute node.

trans-unit.source: The response contains the contents of the RDP file.
trans-unit.target: The response contains the contents of the RDP file.

trans-unit.source: [Get-AzureBatchRDPFile](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt149851.aspx)--This PowerShell cmdlet gets the RDP file from the specified compute node and saves it to the specified file location or to a stream.
trans-unit.target: [Get-AzureBatchRDPFile](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt149851.aspx)--This PowerShell cmdlet gets the RDP file from the specified compute node and saves it to the specified file location or to a stream.
